In line with the extant literature (e.g., Beckmeyer, Branger, and Gayda 2023), we show that volume in 0DTEs now dominates options trading in these underlying markets. To understand how the aggregate open interest in 0DTEs andlonger-maturityoptionsimpactsmarketstability, weanalyzethelinkbetweentheaggregate dollargammainopenoptionpositionsofdifferentmaturitiesandsubsequentintradayunderlying index realized volatility, unconditionally and conditional on lagged volatility. We do not find evidence that the 0DTEs option open interest gamma propagates or uncon- ditionally increases the underlying index volatility. Instead, our results suggest the opposite: higher 0DTE and other short-term options open interest gamma, measured by combining open interest at the market open and options’ dollar gammas shortly after that, predicts lower real- ized volatility within the day and does not propagate overnight and lagged intraday volatilities. There are two plausible explanations for this result. The first is that delta-hedgers are predom- inantly long volatility, and hence, long gamma. As a result, high gamma leads to more intense delta-hedging by gamma buyers, dampening price swings since traders with long gamma posi- tions would sell after the underlying price goes up and buy after the price goes down. Second, in anticipation of low realized intraday volatility, the price of volatility (and option premiums) decreases, and overall open interest increases, reflecting a higher demand at the new price. To the best of our knowledge, our paper is the first to study systematically the effects of aggregate gamma exposure in 0DTEs. Our findings contrast those of Anderegg, Ulmann, and Sornette (2022), Soebhag (2023) and Brogaard, Han, and Won (2023), which either analyze different markets or concentrate on persistent option volume instead of aggregate gamma exposure. text: To ascertain whether market participants price perceived risks, reflected in dollar gamma values, differently in 0DTEs vs. longer maturity options, we examine how open interest gamma for 0DTEs and longer maturity options relate to their respective VRPs unconditionally and conditional on the realized underlying variance. We regress VRP on open interest gamma interacted with both underlying overnight variance and the previous day’s VRP and find no significant relationship between VRPs and open interest gamma for both 0DTEs and longer maturity options, respectively. The interaction of open interest gamma and overnight variance for the underlying is also insignificant across expiration. On the other hand, we find a negative andsignificantcoefficientfortheinteractionofopeninterestgammaandthepreviousday’sVRP for only the short expiration options (0 to 5 DTEs). This result suggests that traders prefer 0DTE options over longer-term options when they have an information advantage in predicting realized over implied volatility in the very short term. 0DTEs’ high leverage and gamma risk make them good candidates for event-based trading. We assess whether these instruments do serve this practical purpose in the market by analyzing the intensity of their use for event-based trading compared to longer maturity options around Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) decision announcements that are known to be as- sociated with the resolution of uncertainty (see, Cieslak, Morse, and Vissing-Jorgensen 2019, Ai, Han, Pan, and Xu 2022). We show that traders use ultra-short-term options, mainly zero- and one-day-to-expiry options, to bet on the resolution of uncertainty. Compared to the longer maturity options, the trading volume in the zero- and one-day-to-expiry options significantly declines in the half-hour interval before FOMC announcements and rebounds significantly after the announcement.
